Def.Name: Rocky Mountain Juniper
Def.Description: Small evergreen tree to 35 feet, often with an irregular crown. Often found on dry, rocky ridges. Slow growing and very long lived.
Def.Leaves: Leaves opposite, scalelike, covering older twigs closely in alternating pairs to 1/4" long. Pale to dark green, on new shoots awl shaped, sharp pointed and spreading; stems short, often dividing near ground.
Def.SeedConeOrFruit: Seed Cones: Blue with whitish bloom, fleshy "berries", 1/4" in diameter, ripening the second season, seeds 1-2" each cone, bony-coated; flowers small, cone-like, borne separately on male and femal plants.
Def.Bark: Red to gray-brown, furrowed, thin and shreddy, branchlets very slender; roots deep, widely spreading.
Def.Range: Wyoming and Colorado at elevations of 5,000 to 7,500 feet.
Def.Remarks: The year-long coloration and attractiveness to wildlife makes this species useful for recreational plantings. It tends to stay green all winter.
